utterances: Okay.

I was actually in Brookhaven, Mississippi, by a great friend and his wife, who took me and my family in, sent to us kind of a spur of the moment thing with the evacuation because the storm kind of grew really fast and came to everyone's attention real quick.
So that was a lot of reason for a lot of the disorganization and everything as it relates to the evacuation.
So I was actually in Brookhaven, Mississippi.
So I had half of my family evacuated and the other half was still here in the city, and some of them were (unintelligible).
I have to say, before I go into further, that area was not the den of poverty and crime and everything like the media makes it.
I wouldn't even be able to go sleep tonight if I didn't say that.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Good point.
So what happened to your family after the storm?
What did you find out about how everybody faired?

Well, the situation was - with the way the communication was - and I think I'm speaking for everybody - is that there was a lot of unknown because you really couldn't contact anyone because of the communications.
The cell phones were down and maybe someone had a text message.
And if their cell phone was working, they couldn't charge the battery.
So I knew I had some family that was living and I knew I had some that weren't accounted for.

And thankfully, I found everybody except for one, which was my grandmother who, I guess, in the chaos and everybody trying to figure out what they'll going to do before the storm, slipped through the cracks, and she didn't make it through.
Did the blog and the blogging help you deal with that kind of loss?
I think it helped me get some of the aggravation out.
Just being able to write it down and express it - I don't know if it helped me any because I haven't found a situation that helped me with it to be totally honest with you.
Right.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But…
The wounds are still fresh, you know.
It was - right.
It was a little therapeutic.
But then, when I realized people was reading it, I kind of took it upon myself to kind of be the voice for a section of the population that the media really doesn't represent…
Mm-hmm.
…or it any leadership for that matter.
So…
So do you…
That's kind of (unintelligible).
Dedra, you seemed to have a knowing chuckle.
I mean, do you do this blog to tell your own story, to inform other people, to motivate people?
And what are you talking about from your personal experience and also from, like, a eagle-eye view of the city?

Partly, I mean, I think I have to agree with Cliff that part of the reason I started blogging was to get some of this anger and the frustration out from, not only what had happened to the city, but how it was being reported on.
And, you know, the perception that, you know, all the black people in New Orleans lived in public housing and were on welfare and were standing there, waiting for someone to help them.
Eighteen feet below sea level.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right.
Oh, yeah.
And we all live 18 feet below sea level.
We're all just, you know, these morons.
And it was - I don't know if I write to motivate, but I feel like I need to do some truth telling.

I need to offer alternative perspectives and some analysis of not only what the news media is reporting locally, nationally and internationally, but also what else is going on the in the ground here and even among other bloggers and misperceptions that even the people who aren't here have about home.
Now, Eban, you are someone who was in the city, and then out of the city, and back in the city.
What are you seeing?
Well, I was born and raised here and, you know, left to go to college 12 years ago.
And then returned last August right after finishing sort of my internship and residency in psychology.
And, you know, I returned in - I guess within a matter of weeks I was so frustrated with what was going on.
You know, having come back about a month before the first anniversary.
And, you know, seeing the lack of progress and hearing the stories of how - oh, wait, you know, the temporary pumps aren't working…
Mm-hmm.
Oh.
…as the storms forming, you know…
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right.
That's definitely a problem.
And, you know, I don't want it to come across as, you know, we think that we are not responsible for any of this.

You know, I will honestly say that - the way that the citizens vote and the things that, you know, the small but powerful and loud parts of the community advocates for in terms of defending politicians, who I don't think deserve it, has held things back, and then kept us from installing leaders who can actually help us.
…the Caribbean and what not.
And actually, I started my blog on August 29th, 2006 because I just got so - and it was a way to vent what, you know, what I was seeing, the progress that wasn't going on.

And the thing that I saw when I got back that irritated me the most, I think, was just all of the misperceptions being put out by the media, which, you know, I don't think it was blatant(ph) on their part.
I think there's just a lot here to understand and a lot of intricacies to what's going on and, you know, that someone who isn't local will probably miss.

Now, Dedra, you - you know, when you go to your Web site, you have the Fleur de Lis symbol and 8/29/2005 remember huge symbol right on your blog and it just says, it's titled, ""We Are Still Not Okay."" What do you mean by that?
Well, you know, it's - there is more to the city that needs to be put back together than the Superdome, and the CBD, and the French Quarter, and St. Charles Avenue.
There are huge - there's still - where most of the people lived, it still looks like the water drained out yesterday.
There's still - the houses are still - people still can't come back.
Our schools are a mess.
Our local government is a mess.

You know, if you don't want - I don't want people thinking that, oh, you know, it's been two years, there have been millions of - billions of dollars poured in, and it's all over and it's fun, and those people should just stop whining.
Right, and if I could just add something to that.
There's been a lot of activity by the citizens themselves.
(Unintelligible).
(Unintelligible) yeah.
Right.

And I think what the frustration, the biggest amount of frustration is that there's all of these people that came together and they're trying to rebuild and they're doing the right thing, but yet you watch the news and you read the newspapers, and it's like, am I wrong for doing this?
I mean…
Right.
Yeah.
Should I just leave like everybody else?
Right.
Yes.
It's sort of like the media and the leadership in the city for that matter, to be totally honest, sort of gives you this feeling like, hey, we told you we weren't really going to do anything.
So you're kind of on your own in this.
Mm-hmm.
And I think that's the point that is harder to get past.
Yeah.

I mean, just on the way here, I heard the governor of Mississippi saying that, you know, they, you know, Mississippi has made a lot of progress, you know, due to the spirit and the character of the people.
And to me, the onset opposite of that is, well, we must not be doing anything…
Right.
…because of our spirit…
Right.
…and character, not because, you know, he's also in the same party as the president, or that they got much more aid in comparison to the amount of damage that they had.
Right.
But we have an incredible - we have a lot of spirit and we have a lot of character.
Yeah.
And that's what got us through so far.
